Mr Gray,

You haven't seen any sidewalks widened? Seriously? What about West Houston Street, Broadway in the heart of Midtown, Lenox Ave in Harlem, Gansevoort St in the Meatpacking district, Madison Square, Union Square, Queensboro Plaza, Main Street in downtown Flushing, Grand Army Plaza, all the ped-only spaces in Lower Manhattan,and the Hub in the Bronx? Perhaps you either need to get out more or think more before writing these posts.

I also object to you labeling of liveable streets advocates as the bike lobby. Go ahead and have a look at what TA and Streetsblog have done and have lobbied for (BRT expansion, ped plazas, traffic calming, sidewalk widening, neckdowns, ped refuges, safe routes to school, safe streets for seniors, fighting service cuts, fighting fare hikes, a long hard fight for congestion pricing). These are off the top of my head, I could go on an on. Yes, advocating for bicycles is a part of that, including opposing measures that have been shown to dramatically reduce cycling. In a few cases those organizations have lobbied for ped improvements that come at the expense of cyclists. Times Square was a prime example of that, and I dare you to find a single instance of Streetsblog or TA doing anything but lending their full and unwavering support of that project. I also dare you to find a single instance of a cyclist describing how much nicer it is to bike through Times Square now. Sure, there are a lot of cyclist involved in those organizations, and cycling has been a big issue recently. However, calling them strictly bike organizations, and lamenting the notion that NYC doesn't have a ped organization is simply disingenuous.

I appreciate the historic perspective that you brought with this article, but I think your rhetoric serves to add fuel to flames, rather than begin real dialogue. Sadly, you're not alone in this.

“All views expressed are our own and do not represent the views of Munich Re. We thank Jan Eichner, Eberhard Faust, Peter Hoeppe, Roger Pielke Jr., Nicola Ranger, Lenny Smith and an anonymous referee for many helpful comments. All errors are ours.”

Outside the US and Germany.

Said wmar:

"HH Lamb created two graphs, one was the UK sometimes referred to as Europe, the other was global, this was the IPCC consensus view of the climate of the past, until Mann's."

A citation would be nice for this claim about two Lamb graphs.

"The graph I posted was the global Lamb Graph which I believe was Figure 7C in the pre-Mann IPCC report."

By this description, it seems clear that wmar did NOT open the link I sent about Lamb and IPCC 1990. Not surprisingly, he/she is arguing with a strawman, and he/she is easily proven wrong to boot.

Open the link. Read more than the opening paragraph:

http://climateaudit.org/2008/05/09/where-did-ipcc-1990-figure-7c-come-fr...

The rest of wmar's Post #55 deals broadly with the idea that the Medieval Warm Period was global enough and powerful enough to give lie to the concept of the temperature hockey stick that the IPCC now endorses. He/she provides a link to a website that has (allegedly) compiled dozens of regional proxy studies that support the proposition of a strong global MWP. Of course, such a list is vulnerable to charges of selection bias, since the list is far from exhaustive. This is the same selection bias that AGW naysayers claim affects the proxy studies used in calculating the hockey sticks, but without vulnerability to peer review.

This circles back around to the fruitless arguments about "my statistician is better than your statistician." When two people with PhD.s start accusing each other of misusing high-level mathematics, the layman who is not inclined to earn PhD.s in the relevant fields is left with no alternative but to either trust or reject the learned consensus.

Sadly, this often boils down to heeding one's political inclinations, rather than logic.

#19, wmar,

Just an example of your truth challenged comments.

The last of your links is to a graph from a blog post that is “derived” from the peer literate, with a caption that does what the paper’s lead author, writing in the same journal, a decade later, say squarely NOT to do.

“The 20,000 year reconstructions presented in HPS97 [the paper that is source for the recent ~2,000 year portray in the graph] utilized observations contained in a database of terrestrial heat flux measurements. Data from the depth range 0–100 meters, the depth range where most of the information about 20th century climate change resides, were excluded from the reconstruction because of noise considerations. Thus the reconstructions derived from that dataset cannot be used to compare the Medieval Warm Period to changes taking place in the 20th century.”

A late Quaternary climate reconstruction based on borehole heat flux data, borehole temperature data, and the instrumental record, S. P. Huang, H. N. Pollack, and P.-Y. Shen, Geophysical Research Letters, VOL. 35, L13703, doi:10.1029/2008GL034187, 2008.

In your comment #2, you cite Clegg et. al. when if fact you cut and pasted from the denialosphere (take your pick of sources) quoting extracts of section 3.1.1 of “Climate Change Reconsidered – 2011 Interim Report”, 2 removes and 2 editorial framings from of what that paper has to say.

As for substance .... so?

You (actually the author(s) of CCR) extract from Clegg its authors saying their results are in broad agree with other regional paleo-temperature studies and the instrument record during Julys. Further, ~1,400 years ago other studies in the general area show cooler temperatures.

That’s hardly support for your “Alaska now is quite chilly, even by judging by only the most recent 3,000 years and would need to warm very dramatically to come close to past warming periods”.

This is the 3rd occasion I’ve taken the time to run down your cites in the last ~2 weeks, 2 from this thread. They are the only ones I’ve investigated in detail, the pattern is clear enough. From the sample of links offered in support of your rhetoric, your contribution here is the mere rhetoric.

wmr (3),
You have quoted the mercurial Dr. Singer who shifted some words and changed the meaning of the quotes reported by Mr. Black. Negligible means negligible and "relatively small compared to natural variability" means something else. Black's quoted the report as using "relatively small" and S. Fred wrote negligible. The difference is important.
You may take comfort in the fact that the sign for the next 20-30 years will be uncertain because of the relatively small signal of AGW over that time frame compared with natural variability.
But if you had honestly reported on the rest of the BBC report, you would have noted that as the century progresses and GHGs accumulate, then the report projects that:
"It is very likely that the length, frequency and/or intensity of warm spells, including heat waves, will continue to increase over most land areas...
"It is likely that the frequency of heavy precipitation or the proportion of total rainfall from heavy falls will increase in the 21st Century over many areas of the globe...
"Mean tropical cyclone maximum wind speed is likely to increase...
"There is medium confidence that droughts will intensify in the 21st Century in some seasons and areas...
"Low-probability high-impact changes associated with the crossing of poorly understood thresholds cannot be excluded, given the transient and complex nature of the climate system."

These projections are pretty much what has been discussed since IPCC AR4 came out in 2007. Mostly they fall within what you would expect for the range IPCC quotes for climate sensitivity. You have constructed a straw man and knocked it down nicely. I recommend that you actually read what IPCC said about natural variability in Section 8.4 of Working Group 1. And I suggest you read the National Academy of Sciences report on Climate Stabilization Targets (2011). Neither IPCC nor the Academy are making the claims that you say are contradicted by the data.
Chuck Wilson
